div1.p: Louise Kean writes about yellow fever research, including the failed experiments of Caldas and Carroll's work.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, August 28, 1901
div1.p:
Yours of the 21st
reached me yesterday,
and I was very much
relieved to have such
good news of Caz. I am
terribly disappointed a-
bout Helen's coming, of
course, for Rannie leaves
about the 10th for Santiago.
But she must come
as soon as she can. The
Gorgases were in here
last night, and they
are going north very soon.
Dr. Gorgas is to attend
some medical meeting
at the Pan-American and
will be returning about
the 20th, Mrs. Gorgas
a little later. They both
of them said they would
be only too delighted to
bring Helen down. Then
Capt. Slocum, and prob-
ably Mrs. Slocum will
be coming this way about
the 7th of October, and they
would take the best of
care of her. Carrie may
be here at the same
time, for she wrote
Rannie asking if she
could come, but she has a scheme for
making the trip via New Orleans, so
I don't know when she will get here. I
have insisted that Mama shall come
back for the winter. For she improved
so much last year I really think an-
other mild winter will be of incalculable
benefit to her. But she will not
come until after Helen has made her
visit; which must not be a short one.
Rannie and I insist upon that.

As to the yellow fever experiments Dr.
Caldas (the Brazilian) has failed en-
tirely. The man he had “immunized”
came down in three days after being
bitten by a mosquitoe. So it will not
be necessary to fool with him any more.
I was not surprised, as his methods
were those of a quack and not a
scientist. I believe the Journal has
mixed up Dr. Gorgas and Dr. Caldas,
and has been raising a row generally,
but I don't suppose anybody pays much
attention to the sayings
of The Journal. Dr.
Carroll will now have
a case or two of experi-
mental fever for his
purposes, and I think
that will be all for Dr.
Caldas is a fake, and no-
body here doubts the mos-
quitoe theory any more.
Aug. 29th.

It was so dreadfully
hot and muggy I could
not finish this yesterday
afternoon. We hear there
is a cyclone south of
us, so we are probably
feeling the effects of it.
This afternoon it is
raining slowly, but
steadily, which is very
unusual for this country.
But fine for the flowers.
They are doing splendid-
ly. I shall be very glad
to have some nastur-
tiuns seeds, but I won't
plant them for another
month, because the worms
eat them up here in
summer, just as they
used to in Key West.
Geraniums only do
pretty well, and we
have some, so don't
bother to send any
of those, but I would
like some parsley seed, if you can
get it.

Bobs has cut one great big tooth, and
another is coming through, I think,
for he has been a little upset for
two or three days.

I am glad to hear Peg is going to
Coburg. I hope the change will do her
a great deal of good. Dr. Field wrote
Capt. Slocum that Doll was the exact
counterpart of me!

A letter came from Carrie today, and
she is still undecided which way to
come, so perhaps if Helen wrote to her
they could arrange to come down together
which would be very nice for them both.
Her address is P. O. Box 22 Wytheville Va.
Evie will spend the winter at Edgehill
I think. The new lieutenants are coming
by every boat, so the girls ought to
have a pretty good time. Rannie
is very well, but terribly busy with esti-
mates. He goes to Matanzas next week for
a few days. Love to all
